assetIdentification.assetDescription: The Vehicle Status Display function is responsible for collecting, processing, and displaying critical vehicle status information to the driver through the instrument cluster. This includes information such as vehicle speed, engine status, fuel level, battery status, warning indicators, and other safety-critical notifications.

confidentiality.justification: The Vehicle Status Display primarily displays information that is not confidential or sensitive from a privacy perspective. The displayed information is meant to be visible to the driver and passengers.

integrity.justification: The Vehicle Status Display must ensure the integrity of all displayed information as incorrect or manipulated information could lead to unsafe driving decisions and potentially cause accidents.

availability.justification: The Vehicle Status Display must remain available and functional during vehicle operation as it provides critical information needed for safe driving, including speed, warning indicators, and system status.

authenticity.justification: The Vehicle Status Display must ensure that all displayed information comes from authentic sources (legitimate vehicle systems) to prevent spoofed or falsified information.

threatScenarios.title: CAN Bus Spoofing of Vehicle Status Data
threatScenarios.description: An attacker gains access to the vehicle's CAN bus (either physically or through a compromised ECU) and injects falsified vehicle status data (e.g., speed, fuel level, warning indicators) that is displayed to the driver, potentially causing the driver to make unsafe driving decisions based on the incorrect information.
attackSteps: Gain access to the vehicle's CAN bus (physically or through a compromised ECU)
Monitor CAN bus traffic to identify message IDs related to vehicle status information
Craft malicious CAN messages with the identified IDs containing falsified data
Inject the malicious messages onto the CAN bus with higher priority/frequency than legitimate messages
Vehicle Status Display receives and displays the falsified information to the driver

controlFlaws: Lack of message authentication on CAN bus allows spoofed messages
No validation of data plausibility before display
Vehicle Status Display cannot distinguish between legitimate and spoofed data sources
Insufficient rate limiting allows flooding of CAN messages
unsafeControlActions: Display incorrect speed information leading to unsafe driving
Display falsified safety warnings causing driver confusion
Suppress legitimate warnings by overriding with normal status data

prerequisiteConditions: Access to vehicle's internal network (physical or remote)
Knowledge of CAN message IDs related to vehicle status information
Ability to transmit messages on the CAN bus

threatScenarios.title: ECU Compromise with Warning Suppression
threatScenarios.description: An attacker compromises an ECU involved in vehicle status monitoring or display control and modifies its firmware to suppress critical warning messages, preventing the driver from being alerted to potentially dangerous vehicle conditions.
attackSteps: Gain access to a target ECU (e.g., Instrument Cluster Controller, Body Control Module)
Extract and reverse-engineer the ECU firmware to identify warning message handling functions
Modify the firmware to filter out or suppress specific warning messages
Reflash the ECU with the modified firmware
Critical warnings generated by vehicle systems are intercepted and suppressed before reaching the display

controlFlaws: Lack of secure boot verification allows execution of modified firmware
Insufficient integrity protection for ECU firmware
No secondary verification of critical warning status
unsafeControlActions: Failure to display critical safety warnings when conditions warrant
Filtering of brake system warning messages

prerequisiteConditions: Specialized knowledge and tools for ECU firmware modification
Ability to bypass ECU security measures (if present)

threatScenarios.title: False Warning Message Injection
threatScenarios.description: An attacker injects numerous false warning messages into the vehicle's communication system, causing multiple non-existent warnings to appear on the Vehicle Status Display, creating driver confusion, anxiety, and potential warning fatigue that leads to ignoring legitimate warnings.
attackSteps: Gain access to the vehicle's CAN bus or communication network
Identify message IDs and formats related to warning messages
Create scripts to generate multiple false warning messages
Inject the false warnings onto the communication bus at random or strategic intervals
Driver is presented with numerous warning indicators causing confusion or warning fatigue

controlFlaws: Lack of message authentication allows injection of false warnings
No rate limiting for warning message frequency
Warning system has no plausibility checks for multiple simultaneous warnings
No cross-validation between warning sources and actual system status
unsafeControlActions: Display too many warnings simultaneously causing cognitive overload
Display contradictory warning messages causing confusion
Display false urgent warnings causing unnecessary driver reaction

prerequisiteConditions: Access to vehicle's internal communication network
Knowledge of warning message protocols and IDs
Ability to transmit messages on the vehicle's communication bus

threatScenarios.title: Display System Denial of Service
threatScenarios.description: An attacker performs a denial of service attack against the Vehicle Status Display by flooding the communication bus with high-priority messages or by exploiting a vulnerability in the display controller, causing the display to freeze, reboot continuously, or become completely non-functional.
attackSteps: Gain access to the vehicle's internal network
Identify high-priority message IDs or discover vulnerabilities in the display controller
Generate excessive traffic on the communication bus targeting the display controller
Alternatively, exploit a vulnerability in the display controller software
Display system becomes unresponsive, freezes, or reboots continuously

controlFlaws: Lack of resource limitation allows message flooding
Insufficient error handling for unexpected message volumes
No redundant display capability for critical information
unsafeControlActions: Failure to display any vehicle status information
Continuous display resets preventing information comprehension

prerequisiteConditions: Knowledge of CAN bus protocols and message priorities
Ability to transmit high volumes of messages or exploit display controller vulnerabilities

attackFeasibilityRating.justification: The attack requires physical access to the vehicle and specialized knowledge of automotive networks, but does not require system privileges or user interaction. The impact on integrity is high as it directly affects safety-critical information.

relevantVulnerabilities: Lack of authentication on CAN bus messages
No message signing for status information
Limited filtering of potentially malicious CAN messages
existingControls: Basic plausibility checks for some vehicle parameters
CAN bus physical access requires vehicle disassembly
Network segmentation between critical and non-critical systems

attackFeasibilityRating.justification: This attack requires physical access to an ECU, high technical expertise for firmware modification, and would typically require privileged access. The attack is complex due to the need for specialized equipment and knowledge.

relevantVulnerabilities: Absence of secure boot mechanisms on some ECUs
Insufficient access controls for ECU reprogramming
existingControls: Some newer ECUs implement code signing
Physical access to ECUs typically requires significant vehicle disassembly
Critical warnings may have redundant display paths in some vehicle systems

attackFeasibilityRating.justification: Similar to TS-VSD-01, this attack requires physical access and automotive network knowledge, but focuses on injecting warning messages rather than status information. It has high integrity impact as it affects the trustworthiness of the warning system.

relevantVulnerabilities: Lack of message authentication for warning indicators
No rate limiting for warning message frequency
Absence of cross-validation between related systems
Limited correlation checks between multiple warnings
existingControls: Some warning messages have priority hierarchy
Critical warnings may have dedicated circuits in addition to CAN messages
Basic filtering of duplicate messages within short timeframes

attackFeasibilityRating.justification: This attack requires physical access and technical knowledge but focuses on availability rather than integrity. The impact on availability is high as it could completely disable the display of critical vehicle information.

relevantVulnerabilities: Susceptibility to CAN bus flooding attacks
Insufficient resource management in display controller
Lack of rate limiting for incoming messages
existingControls: Display controller watchdog timers for crash recovery
Basic error handling for unexpected message formats
Some systems implement message filtering for known invalid patterns

relatedStandards.description: Mitigation to the threats which are related to 'Vehicle communication channels'

relatedRequirements.description: The instrument cluster shall display accurate vehicle status information under all operating conditions
The instrument cluster shall display all critical warning messages triggered by vehicle systems
The instrument cluster shall maintain display functionality in the presence of interference or attack vectors
The instrument cluster shall authenticate the source of all warning messages before display
The instrument cluster shall maintain redundant display capabilities for critical safety information

keyTerms.Threat Scenario: Description of a potential attack against a system, including attack methods and objectives
keyTerms.Attack Vector: Method or path by which an attacker gains access to a system to conduct an attack
keyTerms.Attack Feasibility: Measure of how practical and likely a particular attack is to be executed successfully
keyTerms.CAN Bus: Controller Area Network bus - standard vehicle communication protocol
keyTerms.ECU: Electronic Control Unit - embedded systems controlling vehicle functions
keyTerms.CVSS: Common Vulnerability Scoring System - framework for assessing vulnerability severity
keyTerms.Spoofing: Attack where an entity successfully masquerades as another by falsifying data
keyTerms.Tampering: Unauthorized modification of system, component, or data
keyTerms.Denial of Service: Attack aimed at making a system or resource unavailable
keyTerms.STPA: System Theoretic Process Analysis - safety analysis methodology
keyTerms.Control Flaw: Weakness in a system's control structure that could lead to a hazard
keyTerms.Warning Suppression: Prevention of legitimate warning messages from being displayed

contentSummary: This TARA Threat Scenarios document analyzes four key threat scenarios targeting the Vehicle Status Display function in the Instrument Cluster system. The identified threats are: (1) CAN Bus Spoofing of Vehicle Status Data - falsification of displayed information through injection of spoofed messages; (2) ECU Compromise with Warning Suppression - modification of ECU firmware to prevent critical warnings from being displayed; (3) False Warning Message Injection - generating numerous fake warnings causing driver confusion and warning fatigue; and (4) Display System Denial of Service - preventing the display from functioning through message flooding or component exploitation. Each threat scenario is analyzed in detail, including attack vectors, complexity, prerequisites, and specific attack steps. The STPA analysis identifies control flaws that could enable each attack, such as lack of message authentication, insufficient plausibility checks, and vulnerable error handling. Attack feasibility ratings using CVSS indicate medium feasibility for most scenarios, with ECU firmware compromise rated as more difficult. The document identifies relevant vulnerabilities in current implementations and notes existing security controls. This analysis provides a crucial foundation for risk assessment and security control development to protect the Vehicle Status Display from potential attacks.
